texts.label: paragraph
texts.orig: Most software developers have come across  agile software methodologies  such as  Scrum . At its core, Scrum's goal is to help teams deliver software in smaller chunks over a set period of time, called a sprint. Teams should be able to work better together, deliver more frequently, and adapt to changes more easily.
texts.text: Most software developers have come across  agile software methodologies  such as  Scrum . At its core, Scrum's goal is to help teams deliver software in smaller chunks over a set period of time, called a sprint. Teams should be able to work better together, deliver more frequently, and adapt to changes more easily.

texts.label: paragraph
texts.orig: However, Scrum often becomes a theater of activity -- story points, velocity charts, and ceremony compliance -- that distracts teams from what customers actually need.
texts.text: However, Scrum often becomes a theater of activity -- story points, velocity charts, and ceremony compliance -- that distracts teams from what customers actually need.

texts.label: title
texts.orig: Estimations and exploratory work
texts.text: Estimations and exploratory work

texts.label: paragraph
texts.orig: The world has many, many trades where you can estimate the time and complexity of your work before getting started. If you call a plumber for a leaky pipe, they can estimate the cost and time required to fix it with reasonable accuracy. When your car has a flat tire, the mechanic can tell you how long it will take to fix it and how much it will cost.
texts.text: The world has many, many trades where you can estimate the time and complexity of your work before getting started. If you call a plumber for a leaky pipe, they can estimate the cost and time required to fix it with reasonable accuracy. When your car has a flat tire, the mechanic can tell you how long it will take to fix it and how much it will cost.

texts.label: paragraph
texts.orig: Software development is inherently  exploratory . That's because it involves building something that didn't exist previously. Sometimes there are tools and libraries that speed up development, but these often have limitations that require research.
texts.text: Software development is inherently  exploratory . That's because it involves building something that didn't exist previously. Sometimes there are tools and libraries that speed up development, but these often have limitations that require research.

texts.label: paragraph
texts.orig: As an example, I recently worked on a project that involved adding lots of documents to a retrieval-augmented generation (RAG) system. This is a method for giving an AI model access to information to answer questions that it didn't know already.
texts.text: As an example, I recently worked on a project that involved adding lots of documents to a retrieval-augmented generation (RAG) system. This is a method for giving an AI model access to information to answer questions that it didn't know already.

texts.label: paragraph
texts.orig: Another team had great results with a particular database and mechanism for adding documents, so I was able to utilize most of their strategy. Everything looked like it would be straightforward. An easy ticket with a low estimate; who doesn't love that?
texts.text: Another team had great results with a particular database and mechanism for adding documents, so I was able to utilize most of their strategy. Everything looked like it would be straightforward. An easy ticket with a low estimate; who doesn't love that?

texts.label: paragraph
texts.orig: Then things changed.
texts.text: Then things changed.

texts.label: list_item
texts.orig: The database worked well for their use case, but I had no idea that they were working with a small number of high quality documents in a consistent format.
texts.text: The database worked well for their use case, but I had no idea that they were working with a small number of high quality documents in a consistent format.

texts.label: list_item
texts.orig: Our RAG database build times were much longer than theirs, so we had to search for infrastructure that would allow us to build ours faster.
texts.text: Our RAG database build times were much longer than theirs, so we had to search for infrastructure that would allow us to build ours faster.

texts.label: list_item
texts.orig: Their embedding model for turning text into vectors for a semantic search worked well for their documents but it didn't work for ours.
texts.text: Their embedding model for turning text into vectors for a semantic search worked well for their documents but it didn't work for ours.

texts.label: list_item
texts.orig: We found a better database, but then we had to find out how we could deploy and manage it following our company's procedures.
texts.text: We found a better database, but then we had to find out how we could deploy and manage it following our company's procedures.

texts.label: paragraph
texts.orig: What we thought would be done in a couple of weeks suddenly took a couple of months. We had to come up with new strategies and also think differently about what we would do before and after the RAG search to improve its quality.
texts.text: What we thought would be done in a couple of weeks suddenly took a couple of months. We had to come up with new strategies and also think differently about what we would do before and after the RAG search to improve its quality.

texts.label: paragraph
texts.orig: Time-boxing this work into a sprint was extremely difficult. Estimation was even more difficult because we didn't know the complexity involved and how long it would take. Some of the complexity questions couldn't even be answered because we had dependencies on other teams to complete the work.
texts.text: Time-boxing this work into a sprint was extremely difficult. Estimation was even more difficult because we didn't know the complexity involved and how long it would take. Some of the complexity questions couldn't even be answered because we had dependencies on other teams to complete the work.

texts.label: paragraph
texts.orig: This means we were breaking Scrum's core tenets constantly to deliver the features:
texts.text: This means we were breaking Scrum's core tenets constantly to deliver the features:

texts.label: list_item
texts.orig: We added tickets to sprints after the sprint opened
texts.text: We added tickets to sprints after the sprint opened

texts.label: list_item
texts.orig: We carried lots of issues over to the next sprint as we added new tickets to that sprint
texts.text: We carried lots of issues over to the next sprint as we added new tickets to that sprint

texts.label: list_item
texts.orig: Estimates were wildly inaccurate
texts.text: Estimates were wildly inaccurate

texts.label: paragraph
texts.orig: In the end, we did deliver what was needed, but we often wondered why we were still putting such a heavy emphasis on Scrum.
texts.text: In the end, we did deliver what was needed, but we often wondered why we were still putting such a heavy emphasis on Scrum.

texts.label: title
texts.orig: Interruptions
texts.text: Interruptions

texts.label: paragraph
texts.orig: Interruptions are a fact of life. The Linux kernel deals with this via aptly named interrupts, and it receives signals that something needs attention. It could be events coming from a keyboard or mouse, network packets waiting to be processed, or any number of timers running on the system. The kernel is well suited to handle many of these smaller interrupts. Larger ones lead to heavy context switching and these strain the system.
texts.text: Interruptions are a fact of life. The Linux kernel deals with this via aptly named interrupts, and it receives signals that something needs attention. It could be events coming from a keyboard or mouse, network packets waiting to be processed, or any number of timers running on the system. The kernel is well suited to handle many of these smaller interrupts. Larger ones lead to heavy context switching and these strain the system.

texts.label: paragraph
texts.orig: Software developers are no different. I work with brand new software developers and interns who need guidance from time to time on how to attack a problem. These interruptions are great! Someone gains a new skill and can do more than they previously could. I also reinforce my own knowledge by teaching them. It's usually on a topic that I know well and often tangentially related to what I'm working on anyway.

texts.label: paragraph
texts.orig: Getting into a meeting with multiple engineers on Google Meet to argue about story points, burn down charts, sprint velocity, and other metrics is a different story entirely.

texts.label: paragraph
texts.orig: Standups are excellent, especially for teams with new developers. The other meetings can quickly become a burden.

texts.label: paragraph
texts.orig: If we assume standups are 10 minutes per day and the remaining meetings all last an hour each, that's just under five hours of meetings per two week sprint. That doesn't include other meetings, such as team meetings, company wide meetings, one-on-ones, and mentorship.

texts.label: paragraph
texts.orig: These interruptions can quickly stack up. When you combine software development's exploratory nature with constant ceremony interruptions, you create a recipe for burnout. We should be focused on delivering an outcome or helping a teammate deliver an outcome. Scheduling these around sprint ceremonies wastes time and energy.

texts.orig: [^async standup]: There are synchronous (everyone gets in a meeting together at the same time) and asynchronous (everyone puts their updates in a central place for later review). The async standups definitely save time, but then you lose the ability to ask questions and many developers forget to read the updates.

texts.label: title
texts.orig: Activity over outcomes
texts.text: Activity over outcomes

texts.label: paragraph
texts.orig: When you sit down in your new car for the first time or hold that latest smartphone, you're probably not wondering how many sprints it took to build it. The look of the company's velocity or burn down charts probably won't cross your mind.
texts.text: When you sit down in your new car for the first time or hold that latest smartphone, you're probably not wondering how many sprints it took to build it. The look of the company's velocity or burn down charts probably won't cross your mind.

texts.label: paragraph
texts.orig: As the customer, you're focused on the outcome.
texts.text: As the customer, you're focused on the outcome.

texts.label: paragraph
texts.orig: You name it, I've probably done it at one company or another. Scrum. Waterfall. Continuous flow. Kanban.
texts.text: You name it, I've probably done it at one company or another. Scrum. Waterfall. Continuous flow. Kanban.

texts.label: paragraph
texts.orig: Any of these turns toxic as soon as the focus is on the activity rather than the outcome. Focusing on the activity means putting tons of weight on the processes, the meetings, and the metrics. It means you  say you're interested in the outcomes , but you don't practice that from day to day.
texts.text: Any of these turns toxic as soon as the focus is on the activity rather than the outcome. Focusing on the activity means putting tons of weight on the processes, the meetings, and the metrics. It means you  say you're interested in the outcomes , but you don't practice that from day to day.

texts.label: paragraph
texts.orig: If you want to ensure teams deliver process compliance instead of customer value, lean in really hard on the agile process. Developers work around these processes by doing quite a few unhelpful things:
texts.text: If you want to ensure teams deliver process compliance instead of customer value, lean in really hard on the agile process. Developers work around these processes by doing quite a few unhelpful things:

texts.label: list_item
texts.orig: Avoid creating tickets or create far too many tickets.
texts.text: Avoid creating tickets or create far too many tickets.

texts.label: list_item
texts.orig: Locking themselves into a solution prematurely to ensure something gets done within the sprint.
texts.text: Locking themselves into a solution prematurely to ensure something gets done within the sprint.

texts.label: list_item
texts.orig: Sandbagging estimates to buy time or make things fit into a sprint.
texts.text: Sandbagging estimates to buy time or make things fit into a sprint.

texts.label: list_item
texts.orig: They redefine what "done" means and then add bugs or refinements to later sprints.
texts.text: They redefine what "done" means and then add bugs or refinements to later sprints.

texts.label: list_item
texts.orig: Turn Scrum processes into "meeting theater" where everyone goes through the motions but nobody really cares about the outcome.
texts.text: Turn Scrum processes into "meeting theater" where everyone goes through the motions but nobody really cares about the outcome.

texts.label: paragraph
texts.orig: None of these benefit the team, the leaders, or the end customer. It also pushes developers to look for other teams or other companies that are more focused on outcomes.
texts.text: None of these benefit the team, the leaders, or the end customer. It also pushes developers to look for other teams or other companies that are more focused on outcomes.

texts.label: paragraph
texts.orig: The honest answer is that nobody knows when software will ship. No matter what methodology you use or how hard you push on the agile process, you can't predict the future[^date-driven]. Software development is complex, customer demands change constantly, and new technologies emerge daily. What makes sense on day one of the sprint may not make sense on day 14.
texts.text: The honest answer is that nobody knows when software will ship. No matter what methodology you use or how hard you push on the agile process, you can't predict the future[^date-driven]. Software development is complex, customer demands change constantly, and new technologies emerge daily. What makes sense on day one of the sprint may not make sense on day 14.

texts.label: paragraph
texts.orig: It doesn't have to be this way.
texts.text: It doesn't have to be this way.

texts.label: paragraph
texts.orig: [^date-driven]: There is a concept of "date driven development" where something must ship on time, and in that case, you can drop features or capabilities to ensure on time delivery. You just don't be sure how many features and capabilities the product will have when it ships.
texts.text: [^date-driven]: There is a concept of "date driven development" where something must ship on time, and in that case, you can drop features or capabilities to ensure on time delivery. You just don't be sure how many features and capabilities the product will have when it ships.

texts.label: title
texts.orig: What do we do?
texts.text: What do we do?

texts.label: paragraph
texts.orig: Everything that a team does must be focused on outcomes. This isn't the activity that delivers an outcome, but the outcome itself.
texts.text: Everything that a team does must be focused on outcomes. This isn't the activity that delivers an outcome, but the outcome itself.

texts.label: paragraph
texts.orig: In the past, I worked on a team where we ran Kanban instead of Scrum and we had a "theme" that we worked toward. Kanban is more of a continuous flow methodology with a limit on work in progress items and without a defined time for work. It wasn't the methodology that made us successful. It was the focus on the theme.
texts.text: In the past, I worked on a team where we ran Kanban instead of Scrum and we had a "theme" that we worked toward. Kanban is more of a continuous flow methodology with a limit on work in progress items and without a defined time for work. It wasn't the methodology that made us successful. It was the focus on the theme.

texts.label: paragraph
texts.orig: For example, we had some themes such as "deliver feature X" or "improve cost efficiency of Y to x%". Everyone on the team, including developers, quality engineers, and documentation experts all knew the goal. We could work on whatever we needed to in order to achieve that goal but we could not exceed our work in progress (WIP) limits.
texts.text: For example, we had some themes such as "deliver feature X" or "improve cost efficiency of Y to x%". Everyone on the team, including developers, quality engineers, and documentation experts all knew the goal. We could work on whatever we needed to in order to achieve that goal but we could not exceed our work in progress (WIP) limits.

texts.label: paragraph
texts.orig: As you might expect, someone said  "Hey, what happens if we hit the WIP limit?" Our astute manager at the time knew she had hired talented people who are great at solving tough problems and she was ready with her answer:  "That's for you to figure out."
texts.text: As you might expect, someone said  "Hey, what happens if we hit the WIP limit?" Our astute manager at the time knew she had hired talented people who are great at solving tough problems and she was ready with her answer:  "That's for you to figure out."

texts.label: paragraph
texts.orig: Something interesting happened when we hit the WIP limit for the first time. Sure, the column in Jira turned red and someone mentioned it in Slack, but that isn't what I'm talking about. Someone was freed up on their task and realized they couldn't pull anything else into the "in progress" column.
texts.text: Something interesting happened when we hit the WIP limit for the first time. Sure, the column in Jira turned red and someone mentioned it in Slack, but that isn't what I'm talking about. Someone was freed up on their task and realized they couldn't pull anything else into the "in progress" column.

texts.label: paragraph
texts.orig: They looked in the column for a minute and discovered an issue that was really familiar to them, but it was assigned to someone else. They asked the person working on it if they needed help and the person assigned to the ticket said:  "Yeah, I think I'm stuck!" It turned out to be a great teaching and mentorship opportunity.

texts.label: paragraph
texts.orig: We saw several benefits from being focused on the outcome and not the activity:
texts.text: We saw several benefits from being focused on the outcome and not the activity:

texts.label: list_item
texts.orig: The "stuck" issue didn't appear in the daily standup because the developer was afraid to raise it.
texts.text: The "stuck" issue didn't appear in the daily standup because the developer was afraid to raise it.

texts.label: list_item
texts.orig: Team members focused heavily on the "in progress" column and we discovered that we didn't need standups as often.
texts.text: Team members focused heavily on the "in progress" column and we discovered that we didn't need standups as often.

texts.label: list_item
texts.orig: The theme was our "rally cry" going forward.
texts.text: The theme was our "rally cry" going forward.

texts.label: list_item
texts.orig: Estimating issues turned into more of a discussion of what was involved in solving the issue instead of an exercise in futility.
texts.text: Estimating issues turned into more of a discussion of what was involved in solving the issue instead of an exercise in futility.

texts.label: list_item
texts.orig: Our product owner only needed to ensure the "to do" column was cleaned up and prioritized.
texts.text: Our product owner only needed to ensure the "to do" column was cleaned up and prioritized.

texts.label: paragraph
texts.orig: We still had date constraints, but the  dates were related to when we needed to deliver something to the customer , not arbitrary dates that we set for ourselves. We all knew the dates, the goal, and the overall mission. We knew the what, the how, and the why.

texts.label: title
texts.orig: Summary
texts.text: Summary

texts.label: paragraph
texts.orig: Scrum often transforms software teams into process performers rather than problem solvers. Lighter processes that reinforce the  right behaviors  deliver more value for teams and helps them focus on outcomes. When teams are focused on outcomes, they can adapt to changes, solve problems, and deliver more value to customers. When teams know their "why," they'll figure out the "what" and "how" without rigid processes.
